Reusable and efficient polymer nanoparticles grafted with hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquid catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides Weili Dai ⁎ Ya Zhang Ying Tan Xubiao Luo ⁎ Xinman Tu Key Laboratory of Jiangxi Province for Persistant Pollutants Control and Resources Recycle, Nanchang Hangkong University, Nanchang 330063, Jiangxi, China Key Laboratory of Jiangxi Province for Persistant Pollutants Control and Resources Recycle Nanchang Hangkong University Nanchang Jiangxi 330063 China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Nanchang Hangkong University, Nanchang 330063, Jiangxi, China. Fax: +86 791 83953373. Graphical abstract A novel reusable polymer nanoparticles grafted hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquid (PNPs-HPIL) was first prepared, and evaluated as efficient for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. The as-fabricated PNPs-HPIL catalysts exhibit good catalytic acitivity, stability, and reusability, which are benefical to practical application in industry. A promising new strategy for fabricating polymer nanoparticles that are grafted with hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquid (PNPs-HPIL) through copolymerization of EGDMA and HPIL was established. The PNPs-HPIL catalyst exhibits good catalytic activity for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates through cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. At a catalyst loading as low as 0.47mmol%, the PC yield is above 96.0% and PC selectivity almost 100%. It is noted that the hydroxyl groups of PNPs-HPIL play an important role for facilitating the cycloaddition reaction through the hydrogen bonding between hydroxyl groups and epoxides. Furthermore, the PNPs-HPIL catalyst shows good stability and reusability, which are beneficial to practical application in industry. Keywords Polymer nanoparticles Phosphonium-based ionic liquid CO2 Epoxide Cyclic carbonate 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is regarded both as greenhouse gas and C1 building block. Nowadays, with the concept of green chemistry and sustainable development, chemical fixation of CO2 to useful chemicals has attracted much attention. Although there are over 20 reaction processes that use CO2 as a raw material, successful industrial processes are limited [1,2]. One of the few industrial processes is the synthesis of cyclic carbonates via cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. In terms of “green chemistry” and “atom economy”, this process is promising and attractive, because there is no by-products [3–5]. Moreover, cyclic carbonates as valuable chemicals are extensively used as aprotic solvents, electrolytes in secondary batteries, precursors for synthesizing polymeric materials, and intermediates for the production of pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals, and agricultural chemicals [6–9]. In order to be more efficient in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates through the cycloaddition reaction, a considerable number of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst systems, such as alkali metal salts [10], metal oxide [11,12], modified molecular sieve [13,14], organometallic complexes [15–17], and ionic liquids (ILs) [18,19] were explored. Among them, those of ILs are especially highlighted. Since 2000s, the use of ILs (such as, imidazolium salts [20–23], quaternary ammonium salts [24,25], quaternary phosphonium salts [26–28], pyridinium salts [29], guanidinium salts [30–32], and other ILs [33,34]) as catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides has attracted much interest, because of their negligible vapor pressure and good thermal stability as well as their unique tunable structure and polarity. Compared with imidazolium-based ILs, the quaternary phosphonium-based ILs are not as extensively studied due to the less tailored structures and limited heterogenizing method. Recently, polyfluoroalkyl phosphonium iodides [35], ZnCl2-quaternary phosphonium halides [36], and ZnBr2-Ph4PI [26] systems were evaluated for the cycloaddition reaction. Despite exhibiting good catalytic activity, the systems require harsh reaction conditions and the use of metal halide as co-catalyst. Moreover, the quaternary phosphonium-based ILs, such as PPh3BuBr, PPh3BuCl, PPh3BuI, PPh3EtBr, PPh3PrBr, PPh3HeBr and PPh4I, are themselves low in catalytic activity [26,37]. Recently, however, the “tailor-made” task-specific ILs that were prepared by introducing certain functional groups into the cation and/or anion of traditional ILs, exhibit higher catalytic performance than traditional ILs toward the cycloaddition reaction [20,38–40]. Hereby, we report for the first time the synthesis and evaluation of novel phosphonium-based ILs that are functionalized with hydroxyl, carboxyl and amino groups, as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates through the cycloaddition reaction in the absence of co-catalyst and solvent [28]. The results indicate that those functionalized phosphonium-based ILs show good catalytic activity, especially the hydroxyl- and carboxyl-functionalized ones. However, the inherent homogeneous property of ILs makes them difficult to separate from the products. With good stability and recyclability, it is envisaged that the functionalized phosphonium-based ILs are promising candidates for the fabrication of efficient heterogeneous catalysts by means of heterogenization. Nevertheless, studies on the heterogenization of phosphonium-based ILs are few. Xiong et al. [41] reported a polymer-immobilized tetraphenylphosphonium chloride catalyst that exhibits good activity for the cycloaddition reaction at 160°C and 3MPa in 3h. Two years later the authors reported a polystyrene bead-supported tributylphenylphosphonium chloride catalyst that performed better but under more demanding reaction conditions (150°C, 5MPa, 6h) [42]. Furthermore, Song et al. [43] synthesized fluorous polymer immobilized tributylbenzylphosphonium chloride that showed good catalytic performance. But the high cost of fluorous cross linker, supercritical condition (150°C, 8MPa), and long reaction time (8h) seriously limit its application. It is noted that the active species of the above mentioned catalysts are all traditional phosphonium-based ILs. It is hard to introduce the task-specific ILs onto the support surface, which hinders the improvement of the catalytic performance. Therefore, the development of new and environment-benign heterogeneous phosphonium-based ILs catalysts for efficient synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides is still a challenge. In view of the superiority of the functionalized phosphonium-based ILs reported by us earlier [28]. we synthesized a novel cross-linked polymer nanoparticles that are grafted with hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based IL (denoted herein as PNPs-HPIL). The PNPs-HPIL catalysts were evaluated as reusable and efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides in the absence of co-catalyst and solvent. The influence of hydroxyl groups, the ratio of IL monomer to crosslinker, as well as the reaction parameters (the amount of catalyst, temperature, initial CO2 pressure and time) on catalytic performance were systematically investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents The ethylene glycol dimethylacrylate (EGDMA), 3-bromopropanol, 1-bromopropane, diphenyl(p-vinylphenyl)phosphine, and 2,2′-azobis(isobutyronitrile) (AIBN) were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. Propylene oxide was from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The other epoxides were from Alfa Aesar China Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received. The CO2 (99.9% purity) purchased from Nanchang Guoteng Gas Co. was used without any further treatment. 2.2 Preparation of PNPs-HPIL The steps to prepare the cross-linked polymer nanoparticles that was grafted with hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium IL (PNPs-HPIL) are shown in Scheme 1 . First, diphenyl(p-vinylphenyl)(3-hydroxylpropyl)-phosphonium bromide (denoted as HPIL) was synthesized according to the procedure described in Scheme 1a. In a typical reaction, a solution of diphenyl(p-vinylphenyl)phosphine (4mmol) and 3-bromopropanol (4.4mmol) in 5mL toluene was added into a 50mL flask, and heated at 85°C for 24h under a N2 atmosphere. After reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The top phase was poured out, and the residue was washed twice with toluene and diethyl ether respectively, and then dried at 60°C for 6h under vacuum to give the product HPIL in the form of pale yellow viscous liquid. 1H NMR (400MHz, DMSO-d6, δ/ppm): 7.90-7.37 (m, 14H), 6.91–6.84 (m, 1H), 6.12 (d, J =17.6, 1H), 5.55, (d, J =10.8, 1H), 4.82 (s, 1H), 3.56–3.49 (m, 4H), 1.66–1.64, (m, 2H). HR-MS (QTOF): m/z =428.0734, calcd. for C23H24OPBr (M+H): 428.0728. Then, the PNPs-HPIL catalyst was prepared by radical copolymerization of the as-synthesized HPIL with EGDMA (Scheme 1b). In a typical experiment, HPIL (4mmol), EGDMA (12mmol) and AIBN (1mmol, as initiator) were dissolved in 45mL of acetone. The mixture was heated and subject to reflux for 12h under a N2 atmosphere. After reaction, the as-obtained solid product was filtered out and washed three times with acetone and diethyl ether. Then the solid was dried at 60°C for 6h under vacuum to give the product, denoted herein as PNPs-HPIL-3. Following a similar procedure, the other PNPs-HPIL catalysts, i.e., PNPs-HPIL-1, PNPs-HPIL-2 and PNPs-HPIL-4, were also synthesized by regulating the EGDMA/HPIL molar ratio to 1, 2 and 4, respectively. Moreover, according to the similar preparation procedure of PNPs-HPIL-3, the polymer nanoparticles grafted with triphenylphosphine (denoted as PNPs-PPh3) and triphenylpropylphosphonium bromide (denoted as PNPs-PIL) were synthesized by copolymerization of diphenyl(p-vinylphenyl)phosphine and diphenyl(p-vinylphenyl)propylphosphonium bromide with EGDMA, respectively. The homopolymers using HPIL and EGDMA as monomer were also synthesized, and denoted as P-HPIL and P-EGDMA, respectively. 2.3 Characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) studies were carried out over a Nova NanoSEM 450 microscope. The content of P element was determined by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) using the accessory INCA 250 of the Nova NanoSEM 450. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a SDT Q600 (TA Instruments-Waters LLC) at a heating rate of 15°C/min in a N2 flow. The FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Bruker vertex 70 FT-IR spectrophotometer. 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Bruker 400MHz spectrometer using DMSO-d 6 as solvent. High resolution mass spectra (MS-ESI) were recorded on a Waters Xevo G2-S QTOF. 2.4 Cycloaddition reaction The cycloaddition reactions were conducted in a 50mL high pressure stainless-steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirring bar. In a typical run, the reactor was charged with epoxide (35.7mmol), catalyst (0.47mol%, calculated according to the amount of IL), and appropriate amount of biphenyl (as the internal standard for GC analysis). After the reactor was fed with CO2 to a desired pressure, the autoclave with its contents was heated to a selected temperature and stirred for a designated period of time. Then the reactor was cooled to 0°C in an ice-water bath, and the remaining CO2 was released. The resulting mixture was quantitatively analyzed using a GC with a TCD and were further identified using GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The morphology of catalyst PNPs-HPIL-3 was observed using SEM. As shown in Fig. 1 , PNPs-HPIL-3 is in the form of spherical nanoparticles with several hundred nanometers in size. Despite there is partial aggregation of the particles, most of the nanoparticles can be discerned. The molar ratio of solvophilic HPIL to solvophobic EGDMA was 1:3, and the less amount of the former in polymerization possibly resulted in the aggregation of PNPs during the precipitation process [41]. The main elements of the as-synthesized PNPs-HPIL catalysts were identified and quantified using EDS. The EDS spectra of PNPs-HPIL catalysts show the presence of phosphorus and bromine (Fig. S1, electronic Supplementary material), suggesting the successful grafting of HPIL. Based on the EDS results, the loading amount of IL in PNPs-HPIL-1, PNPs-HPIL-2, PNPs-HPIL-3, and PNPs-HPIL-4 are estimated to be 1.50, 1.15, 1.12, and 0.87mmol/g, respectively. To further confirm the successful grafting of HPIL onto the polymer nanoparticles (PNPs), FT-IR spectroscopic studies were carried out on the as-synthesized PNPs-HPIL catalysts and P-EGDMA (Fig. 2 ). Compared with P-EGDMA (Fig. 2a), all PNPs-HPIL samples (Fig. 2b and c) exhibit characteristic bands of HPIL. The peaks at 1441 and 702cm−1 can be associated with the stretching vibration of PC (Ar) and PC, respectively [42]. The peaks at 1594 and 1488cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibrations of benzene skeleton [44]. The sharp peak at 1117cm−1 belongs to the CO stretching vibration of the hydroxypropyl groups [45]. Furthermore, the broad band in the region of 3300–3500cm−1 is attributed to stretching vibration of OH [45]. The above FT-IR analysis provides clear indication that there was successful synthesis of PNPs-HPIL. The thermal stability of P-EGDMA and catalyst PNPs-HPIL-3 was analyzed by means of TGA. As depicted in Fig. 3 , it is clear that both materials are stable up to 300°C. Upon heating to ca. 700°C, there is the pyrolysis and complete decomposition of P-EGDMA and PNPs-HPIL-3. Unlike P-EGDMA, the decomposition of PNPs-HPIL-3 can be divided into two steps at 300 and 410°C, plausibly attribute to the decomposition of the grafted HPIL (first step) and the polymer matrix (second step), respectively [46]. The results clearly indicate that the as-fabricated PNPs-HPIL-3 shows good thermal stability (up to 300°C). 3.2 Catalytic performance The reaction of propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 to produce propylene carbonate (PC) was chosen as the model reaction to evaluate the catalytic performance of the as-fabricated PNPs-HPIL, and the results are summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen that the polymer support, i.e., P-EGDMA, shows almost no catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reaction (Table 1, entry 1). The ingredients for the formation of PNPs-HPIL, viz. PNPs-PPh3 and 3-bromopropanol also exhibit poor catalytic activity (Table 1, entries 2 and 3). However, high PC yield and almost 100% PC selectivity can be achieved while using PNPs-HPIL as catalysts (Table 1, entries 4–7). Hence, it can be deduced that the hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based IL plays an important role in the reaction. Furthermore, it is noted that the molar ratio of EGDMA to HPIL has slight effect on the catalytic activity of the corresponding PNPs-HPIL catalysts. With the increase of EGDM/HPIL molar ratio from 1/1 to 4/1, the PC yield only increases from 96.6 to 97.8% (Table 1, entries 4–7). The phenomenon is plausibly attributed to the good dispersity of PNPs in the reaction system, which enhances the interaction between the IL and the PO, thus promoting the cycloaddition reaction. In the case when HPIL was used as homogeneous catalyst, 99.5% of PC yield was obtained (Table 1, entry 8). While using PNPs-HPIL-3 and PNPs-HPIL–4as heterogeneous catalysts, the PC yield are 97.3 and 97.8%, respectively (Table 1, entries 6 and 7). Obviously, there is only slight decline of activity in the cases of PNPs-HPIL-3 and PNPs-HPIL-4 in comparison with that of HPIL. The results demonstrate that the PNPs-HPIL catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity nearly as good as that of homogeneous HPIL, which is a result of the good dispersity of PNPs-HPIL in the reaction system. To further certify the above estimation, the time for the cycloaddition reaction over HPIL was shortened. It was found that the PC yields in 3 and 4h (76.6 and 92.7%; Table 1, entries 9 and 10) are much lower than that in 5h (99.5%; Table 1, entry 8). The results indicate that the deduction based on the comparison of catalytic activities of PNPs-HPIL-3 (or PNPs-HPIL-4) and HPIL is reasonable and accountable. Moreover, compared to PNPs-HPIL, P-HPIL that was prepared through homopolymerization of HPIL shows much lower activity (Table 1, entry 11). It is probably due to the insufficient use of active sites of the latter that is large in the density of active sites. Furthermore, chitosan-grafted 1-butyl-triphenylphosphonium bromide (denoted as CS-[BuPh3P]Br) was prepared by our group and evaluated as efficient catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction [44]. In order to make a direct comparison, we evaluated CS-[BuPh3P]Br under the same conditions adopted in this study, and the yield is 36.0% (Table 1, entry 15), much lower than that observed when PNPs-HPIL are used (96.6–97.8%; Table 1, entries 4–7). Furthermore, the catalytic activities of PNPs-HPIL are comparable to that observed by Song et al. [43] over fluorous polymer immobilized tributylbenzylphosphonium chloride that was performed under harsher reaction conditions (1mol% of catalyst, 150°C, 8MPa and 8h). It is apparent that the PNPs-HPIL catalysts show a much satisfactory performance, and have great potential for practical application as heterogeneous catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. In our previous study [28], hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based ILs as homogeneous catalysts exhibit superior catalytic performance than the traditional phosphonium-based IL. Herein, we elucidated the role of hydroxyl groups of PNPs-HPIL catalysts through comparison with the PNPs-PIL catalyst without hydroxyl group. It can be seen that only 60.1% of PC yield can be obtained over PNPs-PIL (Table 1, entry 12), which is much lower than those over PNPs-HPIL catalysts (96.6–97.8%; Table 1, entries 4–7). Furthermore, when hydroxyl-containing compounds, such as methanol and water, were deliberately added to PNPs-PIL, there is significant rise of catalytic activity as demonstrated in the PNPs-PIL/H2O and PNPs-PIL/CH3OH cases (Table 1, entries 13 and 14). It is apparent that the hydroxyl groups of the as-synthesized PNPs-HPIL facilitate the proceeding of the cycloaddition reaction. It was reported that the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides follow a three-step mechanism, viz. ring-opening of epoxides, insertion of CO2, and the intermolecular cyclization [20–23,38,39]. Normally, the ring-opening step is rate-determining, which can be promoted by both the nucleophilic attack of an anion on the C atom of epoxide and electrophilic attack of a cation on the O atom of epoxide [47]. Additionally, it was well demonstrated that the hydrogen bonding formed between hydroxyl group and oxygen atom of epoxide has a positive effect on the epoxy ring-opening, thus facilitating the cycloaddition reaction [20–23,38,39]. To confirm the hydrogen bond interaction, PNPs-HPIL-3 and a mixture of PNPs-HPIL-3 and PO were characterized by FT-IR analysis. It can be seen in IR spectra (Fig. 4 ) that the characteristic absorbance of the hydroxyl groups at 3456cm−1 due to the stretching vibrations of OH groups of PNPs-HPIL-3 shifts to 3348cm−1. That suggests hydrogen bonding between hydroxyl groups and PO, which is consistent with the results reported by Cheng et al. [48]. Moreover, Wang et al. [47,49] studied the mechanistic details of cycloaddition of CO2 with PO catalyzed by functionalized ILs through DFT method. It was found that: (1) the barrier height of ring-opening step is higher than the ring-closing step while using hydroxyl-functionalized ILs as catalysts, testifying that the ring-opening step is rate-determining; (2) the barrier height of ring-opening step by using hydroxyl-functionalized ILs as catalysts is much lower than that using the corresponding traditional ILs, a result of strong hydrogen bonding between hydroxyl groups and epoxides. The experimental and theoretical results strongly suggest that the presence of hydrogen bond between hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based IL and epoxide plays an important role in promoting the cycloaddition reaction [22]. Based on our results and those of previous reports [20–23,38,39,47,49], a possible mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 to PO over PNPs-HPIL is suggested. As shown in Scheme 2 , the coordination of OH with the O atom of epoxide first occurs through hydrogen bonding, resulting in polarization of epoxide CO bond. Meanwhile, there is nucleophilic attack of Br− on the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of epoxide, which promotes the ring opening of epoxide and generation of oxy anion intermediate. Then, the CO2 further interacts with the ring-open intermediate, resulting in the formation of linear halocarbonate. Finally, the cyclic carbonate is formed through intramolecular ring-closure with simultaneous release of Br− and regeneration of the catalyst. 3.3 Effects of reaction parameters Since catalyst PNPs-HPIL-3 shows good catalytic activity, we investigated the influence of reaction parameters (i.e., catalyst loading, temperature, pressure, and time) over PNPs-HPIL-3. The cycloaddition reaction of PO with CO2 is also chosen as the model reaction. Fig. 5 shows the effect of catalyst amount on PC yield and selectivity. With increasing the catalyst amount from 0.05 to 0.15g, the PC yield sharply rises from 60.2 to 97.3%. Further increase in the amount of catalyst does not produce significant increase in the PC yield, which is because that the excess catalyst could not be well dispersed in the reaction mixture, thus limiting the mass transfer between active sites and substrates [50]. Apparently, it is a promising result that PNPs-HPIL-3 exhibits high catalytic activity at low catalyst amount (0.15g, 0.47mmol%). Furthermore, the PC selectivity is almost independent of the catalyst amount. Almost all the reports on the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides indicate that reaction temperature and CO2 pressure significantly affect the cycloaddition reaction. As shown in Fig. 6 , the temperature has a pronounced positive effect on the cycloaddition reaction when it is varied from 110 to 150°C. In the range of 110–140°C, the PC yield increases sharply (from 70.9 to 97.3%) with increasing temperature; thereafter, further increase in temperature results in only slight increase of conversion. In many reports, there is a decline of PC selectivity at temperature above 130°C (or 140°C) by using other ILs as catalysts, which may be attributed to the acceleration of side reactions such as isomerization to acetone, hydrolysis to diol, and/or thermal polymerization [34,40,51–58]. In this study, however, the selectivity to PC stays high (>99.4%) throughout. It was reported that higher temperature (>130°C) and stronger acid-basic property of catalyst (such as ZSM-5 and Salen-Co complex) could facilitate the side reactions [59–61]. Hence, we speculate that the relatively weaker Lewis acid-basic property of HPIL possibly hinder the side reactions, thus resulting the high PC selectivity throughout the cycloaddition reaction. The effect of CO2 pressure on the reaction was also investigated at 140°C with a reaction time of 5h (Fig. 7 ). It is observed that PC selectivity is always above 99.4% and can be considered as being independent of CO2 pressure. However, the change of pressure can have a great influence on the reaction conversion. With rise of CO2 pressure from 1.0 to 2.0MPa, there is a rapid increase of PC yield, whereas further rise from 2.0-3.0MPa, slight decrease of PC yield. Such an effect of CO2 pressure on catalytic activity were also observed in other catalytic systems [4,42,56,57,62]. It can be explained that high CO2 pressure could reduce PO concentration in the vicinity of the catalyst as a result of dilution by excessive amount of CO2, thus resulting in lower reaction efficiency. Accordingly, the appropriate CO2 pressure would be 2.0MPa. Moreover, the dependence of PC yield and selectivity on reaction time was evaluated. It was found that the reaction time has a remarkable influence on the cycloaddition reaction. As illustrated in Fig. 8 , the cycloaddition reaction proceeds rapidly to reach a PC yield of 97.3% within the first 5h. Prolong of reaction to 9h, only results in a slight rise of PC yield, maybe due to the achievement of chemical equilibrium. Remarkably, the selectivity to PC remains above 99.5% in the entire reaction process. 3.4 Recycling studies As well known, the reusability and stability of the catalyst are two key factors to identify whether it has potential for practical application in industry. To test the catalyst reusability, a series of cycles were run over catalyst PNPs-HPIL-3 under the same conditions. In each cycle, the catalyst was recovered by simple filtration, and subject to washing and drying before directly used for the next run. From Fig. 9 , it is clear that the catalyst performs well across the six consecutive cycles without any significant loss of activity, affirming good reusability of the catalyst. Then the catalyst after the sixth run was subject to SEM, TGA, and FT-IR analysis. From the SEM images (Fig. S2, electronic Supplementary material), it is found that the morphology and particle size of the recovered catalyst are almost similar to those of fresh PNPs-HPIL-3. Also, according to the TGA results, the recovered catalyst is similar to the fresh catalyst in terms of thermal stability, both stable up to ca. 300°C (Fig. S3, electronic Supplementary material). Furthermore, the FT-IR spectra of fresh and recycled catalyst are alike (Fig. S4, electronic Supplementary material). The results show that the PNPs-HPIL-3 catalyst is thermally as well as chemically stable in the reaction. Therefore, the as-fabricated catalyst has high potential for application in fixed bed reactor to continuously synthesize cyclic carbonates in a large scale. It is noted that there is no application of any heterogeneous catalysts for industrial production of cyclic carbonates. 3.5 Catalytic activity toward different epoxides In order to study the efficiency and general applicability of the developed catalytic system, the cycloaddition of CO2 with various epoxides was studied, and the results are listed in Table 2 . It can be observed that the catalyst PNPs-HPIL-3 is efficient for the terminal epoxides, and all reactions run smoothly, showing appreciable yield of the corresponding cyclic carbonates. Among them, the cycloaddition of CO2 to PO and epichlorohydrin proceed well, giving almost quantitative yield of the corresponding products in 5h (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). The reactivity of styrene oxide (Table 2, entry 3) is slightly lower than that of PO and epichlorohydrin, probably due to steric hindrance at the β-carbon atom that restricts nucleophilic attack of bromine anion on the epoxy ring. Notably, due to the large steric hindrance, cyclohexene oxide (Table 2, entry 4) exhibits relatively low activity for the cycloaddition [20,21,38,39]; only 46.8% of PC yield can be obtained for a much longer reaction time (24h). Moreover, the DFT studies reported by Wang et al. also testify this result [47]. It was found that the barrier height of ring-opening of epoxide (rate-determining step) using cyclohexene oxide as substrate (29.2kcal/mol) is much higher than that using PO as substrate (19.4kcal/mol). This indicates that the bulky steric hindrance of cyclohexene oxide weakens the nucleophilicity of Br− anion, and restricts the ring-opening of epoxide, consequently lowers the reactivity. 4 Conclusion A series of cross-linked polymer NPs grafted with hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based ILs was prepared and evaluated as efficient and reusable heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides in the absence of any solvent and co-catalyst. Over the as-fabricated PNPs-HPIL, above 96.0% PC yield and almost 100% PC selectivity can be obtained at low catalyst loading of 0.47mmol%. It is noted that the molar ratio of cross-linker (EGDMA) to HPIL shows only slight effect on the activity of PNPs-HPIL, probably due to the good dispersity of PNPs-HPIL. Compared to PNPs-PIL without hydroxyl groups, the PNPs-HPIL catalysts exhibit much superior catalytic activity. This can be interpreted as the formation of hydrogen bonding between hydroxyl group and epoxides has a positive effect on epoxy ring-opening that is crucial for the cycloaddition reaction. Moreover, the catalyst shows good thermal stability and excellent reusability in a test of six cycles without showing any significant loss of activity. Hence, in terms of simplicity, stability, and reusability, the catalyst is attractive for industrial production of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. coredata.dc:description: A promising new strategy for fabricating polymer nanoparticles that are grafted with hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquid (PNPs-HPIL) through copolymerization of EGDMA and HPIL was established. The PNPs-HPIL catalyst exhibits good catalytic activity for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates through cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. At a catalyst loading as low as 0.47mmol%, the PC yield is above 96.0% and PC selectivity almost 100%. It is noted that the hydroxyl groups of PNPs-HPIL play an important role for facilitating the cycloaddition reaction through the hydrogen bonding between hydroxyl groups and epoxides. Furthermore, the PNPs-HPIL catalyst shows good stability and reusability, which are beneficial to practical application in industry.
coredata.dc:title: Reusable and efficient polymer nanoparticles grafted with hydroxyl-functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquid catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides
